title: Is there such a thing as a nice script font?
content:
I need a 'nice' bold script font... I've always pretty much hated script, I think we are taught at design school to hate scripts. But anyway, a fellow designer has given a client a logo design in a script font, the job has now passed to me, and Iam meant to find a sellection of nice bold script fonts to give the client some kind of choice..   
   
any idea's?
author: union

comments.content:
Cocktail Shaker, League Night, The new Veer One from Jukebox . . .   
   
:D

Bickham Script from Adobe is quite well done and has very nice swash caps.   
\< [http://www.adobe.com/type/browser/p/p\_1421.jhtml](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/p/p_1421.jhtml)\>   
 [http://www.adobe.com/type/browser/gifs/BICQ/B\_BICQ-10012000.GIF](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/gifs/BICQ/B_BICQ-10012000.GIF)

[Sarah Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.letterheadfonts.com/contributors/charlesborges/sarahscript.shtml) from Letterhead Fonts is great... we just bought it a few months ago.
What style of script are you looking for?

Try Monotype Script:   
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/monotype-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/monotype-script/)   
It reminds of Coca-Cola, and most people love coke - or Pepsi, same difference.   
   
Speaking of scripts, I'm doing these letterpress cards (sort of as a joke - more during TypeCon) and I found this pretty amazing old script face from the Tetterode/Amsterdam foundry - you wouldn't _believe_ how self-conscious it is - I should have a showing in mid-July.   
   
hhp

Mark Simonson's [Coquette](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.ms-studio.com/FontSales/coquette.html) ... one of my favorite scripts.   
   
But are there no specifics? Style?   
   
hrant, pepsi and coke ARE NOT the same thing.

[Tiki Holiday](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/houseind.com/house.php?kit=TIKICD-FO&sub=view)   
   
 [Lamplighter Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.fontdiner.com/main.html) -- guess this one isn't very bold though. :/   
   
 [Suburban](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=122) -- a sans serif with script-like tendencies   
   
 [Sodascript](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=120) -- an italic sans with script-like detailing

_hrant, pepsi and coke ARE NOT the same thing._   
   
Politically speaking: yes they are. I wouldn't drink either one. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

TUXEDO SCRIPT / FRANCIS   
 [http://lanstontype.com/Francis.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/lanstontype.com/Francis.html)   
   
LANSTON SWING BY SOL HESS   
 [http://lanstontype.com/LanstonSwing.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/lanstontype.com/LanstonSwing.html)   
   
Not a script, but "script like", new at Lanston.   
POSH INITIALS BY JIM RIMMER   
 [http://lanstontype.com/Posh-Initials.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/lanstontype.com/Posh-Initials.html)

"I think we are taught at design school to hate scripts."   
   
I think at my design school in Italy they don`t know   
what you are talking about. I might be wrong.   
   
I like those:   
   
Caflisch Script   
Good Dog Plain   
EF Kaufmann Bold

[Poetica](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1439.jhtml) and [Brioso](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1503.jhtml), both by Robert Slimbach are masterful, formal typographic scripts.

There are hundreds of different kinds of script. What kind of style are you seeking? A single category -- 'script fonts -- that includes all the examples so far suggested in this thread is a category that is too broad to be useful.

Danubia script is foxy, and more "typographic" than most...   
   
 [http://tinyurl.com/3364n](http://web.archive.org/web/20090612191114/http:/tinyurl.com/3364n)
